course.subject: HUMA
course.name: Appreciation of Western Art
course.description: An introduction to the appreciation of art through selected works of architecture, sculpture, and painting from the West, from the ancient periods to the present day.

reviews.author: Flora6293
reviews.comment_content: It's all about art elements, the history of art (from the classical period to modern art) .
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor always changes her mind about the grading system. Ridiculously, she decided to add extra 2 points to year 1 n 2 students and groups who presented on the first day of the presentation period after all the presentations ended.

Also, her class is quite boring and sometimes she tries to engage with students.
reviews.comment_grading:
Attendance (10%) (At first, the syllabus said it will randomly take 10 classes attendance, but it turns out the TA took every lesson, so better attend all the lessons.)
Project (x%) ( project will be scored based on individual presentation skills, time spent, research, etc.)
Mid-term (fill in the blanks + short q)
Final  (fill in the blanks + short q + 1/3 essays)
If you are good at memorizing, mid-term and final would be easy for you)

If the professor did not add extra 2 points to students suddenly, I will have a higher grade lol
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is fair for a 3 credit course.

reviews.author: briiiii
reviews.comment_content: Learn about Classical art, renaissance, baroque, neo-classicism, romanticism, modern, impressionism and more. One challenge would be that you will have to memorise name of artists and artwork, which many of them are in Italian. Easy to get A range if you're interested in history of art or good at memorising . There are quite a few field trips to galleries. Last semester, we went to K11 atelier to watch the Glow like that exhibition. For group project, you are allowed to form your own group and will have to pick a modern artwork to research on and present. The artwork has to be exhibited in HK during the time period she has set, hence you will have to go to different exhibitions with your group mates.
reviews.comment_teaching: Content is interesting if you're genuinely interested in western art.  She is a very nice teacher and always willing to answer questions and give you guidance through your group project. However, she normally just reads off the powerpoint, hence classes can sometimes be quite boring
reviews.comment_grading:
10% class participation
25% group project
25% mid term
40% Final

*She gives out attendance sheet irregularly for 10 times , so make sure you attend every class
*for midterm, 2 weeks ahead of normal midterm time for other courses, which I thought is good as this is a content-rich course and requires a lot of memorising. Midterm only includes MC
*Final is non-cumulative
*Grade distribution for final: 30% for MC and 10% for short essay. There will be three questions you can choose from for the short essay and you only have to answer one of them. Some print-outs of paintings related to questions will be provided.

I would say Midterm and Final are relatively easy if you've gone through the ppt slides thoroughly
reviews.comment_workload: 1 group project + group presentation, 3 non-compulsory (not graded) assignments, 1 midterm and 1 final

reviews.author: Rosie
reviews.comment_content: The content of the course mainly focuses on the history and appreciation of western art. The materials she provides are very comprehensive and she recommends a lot of further reading so it'll be a very interesting course if you're genuinely interested in Art History and Western Art. It is quite a reading-intensive course that requires quite some memorizing to prepare for the tests. But there isn't any written assignments! (Just some, occasionally, and mostly optional)
reviews.comment_teaching: She is a very passionate and amiable teacher who is willing to answer your questions on art. She is also very dedicated in her teaching even though it could be boring to some (So, make sure you really like the subject!). Her lectures are pretty interesting because she gives elaborations and examples outside of her powerpoint slides. She's definitely a great professor!
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is considerably fair. There are weekly assigned readings that could deepen your understanding on the topics she is covering. You can choose not to read them and just focus on the powerpoint content but if you truly want to learn more about Western Art, the reading assignments are very useful! They're not as heavy as some courses. There aren't any written assignments (Just some occasionally and mostly optional). But doing them really helps you better grasp the topics and apply the theories into analysis which are really helpful when it comes to the final group project!

reviews.author: Chromium
reviews.comment_content:
Main topics:
- methodology of art appreciation
- Language of Art
- Materials & Techniques
- Art Genres (History, Portraiture, Genre, Landscape & Still Life)
- From Classical Art to Renaissance
- High Renaissance
- Baroque Art
- Neoclassicism & Romanticism
- Impressionism
- Modern Art
- Human Body
- Artist & Patronage
- Social & Historical Contexts
- Gender & Ethnicity
- Rethinking Art

The contents are pretty rich and extensive. Lecture notes in form of PPTs are provided. They include brief descriptions with the aid of images of related artworks.
reviews.comment_teaching:
- Generally quite good
- Easy to follow & understand
reviews.comment_grading:
Pretty good as long as you work hard.

Grading:
- mid-term exam: 25%
- group presentation: 25%
- final exam: 40%
- attendance: 10%

Grade cutting (as of this semester):
- A+: 90+
- A: 87-89
- A-: 83-86
- B range: ~75-82
- C range: ~50-74
reviews.comment_workload:
1 mid-term exam
- requires memorization of lecture notes

1 group presentation
- 3 to 4 students per group, 15 minutes
- choose one artwork created in a Western art medium found in HK
- it would be enough if you apply some rules from the lecture notes appropriately

1 final exam
- non-cumulative
- requires memorization of lecture notes

Weekly reading assignments
- extracted from two textbooks
- not a must, but help you learn more in a detailed manner

Gallery visits
- voluntary

reviews.author: yummylemonade
reviews.title: Take it if you are good at memorizing facts
reviews.comment_content: The content covered a lot of factual and historical stuff about different art period, styles, artists etc. It was quite a lot of content being covered in a short period of time, such that if you are not good at memorizing stuff don't take this course, as the professor likes to ask some specific words that you see in the powerpoint as midterm/final exam questions. However, since the questions in the exams are very straight-forward and doesn't required critical thinking, it means that you would be able to get the answers right if you have study, read through the powerpoint thoroughly, and really memorize all the materials in the ppt then you would be good to go. All in all, I think this is a good course for you to gain adequate and introductory knowledge on western art, but only take it if you are willing to spend LOTS of time to memorize the factual materials.
reviews.comment_teaching: I would have to be honest the teaching is quite boring because the instructor just directly said the things from the powerpoint. But I understand that the instructor is also very passionate about the stuff that she is teaching. The instructor would research thoroughly on the artwork that you have chosen for your project, and would give out comments openly in lesson time after all the presentations have finished, so don't try to make up something because she always know if that is true or not haha.
reviews.comment_grading: I think the grading is good but not the best. The instructor is quite generous on giving out mark i think, even if students spell some terms wrong in the mid-term exam, she would still give out mark. (on the other note, there are lots of technicals terms that are not only in English, but other languages, so it requires you to look up those words in order to have a great understanding of the content) But overall, the distribution of grade is quite good, I think if you get a slightly above mean in general, you would get B range but not C, so it's better than the normal courses in UST.
reviews.comment_workload:
- one group presentation on a choice of your artwork
- one midterm exam (fill in the blanks, mc, T/F)
- one final exam (same as midterm but with one more essay question)
- attendance
- optional reading materials (same content as the ppt, but the readings would help you understand the ppt much more)
- optional assignments to hand in

Since there is a lot of content being taught in class, you really need some time to go through it

reviews.author: troll
reviews.comment_content: Rich content about Western art which mainly focuses on learning styles and characteristics across different periods. The lectures slides are almost the same as what she mentioned in class. (So if you missed the class or not paying attention in class has no serious impact on your study.) But there are quite a lot of lecture slides per lesson and therefore it could be boring sometimes.
reviews.comment_teaching: Anna is a very nice teacher but her lessons could be very boring if you are not very interested in Western art and what she says is basically what she prepared on the PPT.

The grading is fair. Anna welcome any of us to check the paper and discuss ans if her if you have any questions with her marking.

reviews.comment_workload:
Exercise are optional and she will mark it and return to you.
Ans will be provided in next lessons' PPT.

reviews.author: Cary.R
reviews.comment_content: The contents are really helpful and fulfill my expectation for the class. Ranging from Baroque to Modern Art, basically you will have a close look into the art history.
reviews.comment_teaching: She teaches very well but many contents are listed on PPT, so what you 've heard is basically somehow the same as the words on ppt.
reviews.comment_grading: well I am quite satisfied cuz I didn't go through reading materials at all. I only spared 3 days to memorize all the points and prepared the essay the professor needed. Answer to many questions can be find on ppt so all you need to do is to go through ppt carefully with patience.
reviews.comment_workload: What's more can I say? If you wanna learn something, HUMA1650 is a very good class but speaking of workload, it's a totally different situation. If you wanna get good grades, there are soooooo many things you need to memorize just like typical kinda of humanities class. But if you choose to escape from the diligent hard work like me, you can be quite relaxed. So what i can say is it depends on you.
